blog.description:
My name is Missa. I'm a 20 year old Aquarius who blogs about dumb nerds I'm in love with all day and changes the code on my blog every week. INFP/Knight of Heart
she/her pronouns
Everything else is in my about me!

tags: i read the book a few years ago so i keep spoiling things for him too
summary: I think the subtext in Good Omens is so overt that even my boyfriend (who i have to point out most subtext to in most shows bc...
body: I think the subtext in Good Omens is so overt that even my boyfriend (who i have to point out most subtext to in most shows bc hes kinda non-observant) watches Crowley and Aziraphale interact and goes: …what kind of gay shit… is this…

summary: i know michael sheen has said (iirc) that crowley handing him his rescued books is the moment aziraphale realized he was in love...
body: i know michael sheen has said (iirc) that crowley handing him his rescued books is the moment aziraphale realized he was in love but i’m pretty sure crowley has been excruciatingly aware that he was helplessly in love from the moment azi shielded him from the rain with his wing and my heart can’t take it

summary: In the Beginning
title: In the Beginning
body:
They all used to pray. Even the Big Guy. It was outlawed to speak the Creator’s name, but they were demons.

Many of the smaller ones, the ones from the lower tiers, wept as they did so. Before the halls of Hell even had one soul, it was full of weeping.

It was rumored those smaller ones disappeared to be shades.

Over the years, the prayers stopped and their angelic threads finally, completely, turned to bitter rot.

Save for one.

An Angel prays through song. But weeping and screaming during a Fall don’t really help the throat.

Crowley, out in the Garden, looked up at the sky. He had prayed after the Fall. He didn’t want to go back, as he had never been happy up there, but he didn’t see why it had to be an All or Nothing kind of deal. Maybe he could stay here, in the Garden. He knew the humans were to be tested, and no snotty Angel was going to want to test them.

“OoOoH what if we are punished for their failure?”

Crowley hissed in displeasure. They covered up their cowardice with privilege. It wasn’t as if the Divine God themself would allow for the exquisite Metatron to debase himself as some sort of trickster for the humans. Let the stupid putti do that.

“God, you saved me from the fools before, save me once again.” Crowley muttered as he clambered through the dense foliage.

He could do it. He would do it if they would let him stay. It was nice here. Not great, but nice. There was no conflict to change things but at least there were creatures to annoy and different things to eat. (The roses gave him a twisting gut though.)

“Let me stay.” Crowley whispered. “Let me have the peace you promised us all up there. I never got the chance.”

He was glum. Not quite self-pitying like the other demons, just put out. He wondered why he had been made at all if he was just going to come out wrong.

“You’re never wrong.” Crowley said as he tried to barter. “And my Divine Purpose couldn’t’ve been to end up damned. That’s not fair.”

There was a clearing and a light ahead. There was no need for a light in the Garden and the nights were filled with the ethereal twinkling of the stars anyway.

“An Angel.” Crowley determined in a mocking tone. He slithered away till he found a private place. There was no one here he really wanted to talk to, not really. Maybe one, if she was as interesting as he hoped.

More than the Garden, Crowley really did like the Woman. She was shaped by the Creator but made, literally, of Man. She was the first earth made thing and that pleased Crowley for some reason. Created, but with the imperfect dust in her very blood.

It made her special. Unlike anything else in the whole Garden.

Adam named her, of course, which irked Crowley. She should have her own name, and her own place in all this mess.

When she ultimately found him, on that night, Crowley was surprised.

“And what are you called?” Her voice, like wind, made him jump in the branches.

“Ah, well, ehm.” Crowley cleared his throat and hid behind some leaves. “I’m Crowley. Now. Wasn’t before. Didn’t much like that name though. Too many syllables.”

Crowley babbled as he darted over branches, trying to escape her curious eyes.

“You can change your name?” She asked. Questions, only questions so far. Adam made statements and this one questioned. That wouldn’t do her any good, Crowley knew that from experience.

“Sure. Hey, should you be here?” Crowley asked. He was sure there had been that same Angel guarding this tree. The Angel that kept getting distracted to go look at something.

“Should you? Did Aziraphale let you in here too?” The woman asked. Crowley stopped on a branch, making a face as he tilted his head back and forth.

“Not quite.” Crowley admitted.

The woman’s face suddenly appeared as she moved some of the leaves. She looked surprised, but not disgusted.

“Why do you look like that?” She asked.

“A little bit of everything isn’t it? I like it. I used to look like the Angel.” Crowley remarked.

“Your eyes.” She said and Crowley turned his head. “They look like his sword.”

He puffed up a bit at that.

“How can I change?” She asked suddenly and Crowley deflated.

“Nothing changes here. You’d need conflict for that.”

“How do I find conflict?”

“By making a choice. Usually one that contradicts what someone else has said.”

“What is a choice?”

Crowley sighed and ambled over the branch. He bumped into a jeweled fruit and quite suddenly had an idea.

“God told you not to eat of this tree.” Crowley said. He didn’t know what was so special about this tree, it seemed much like the others. The fruit didn’t even taste that great and it had a sizeable pit.

“You just have to ask yourself, do you want to try it?” Crowley asked.

The woman looked at the tree, at the fruit that Crowley had begun to coil around.

She nodded.

“I do.”

A simple vow, a simple choice. Crowley moved away from the fruit and the Woman grabbed it.

“Mind the stone. It would hurt you given half a chance.” Crowley advised as she bit into it. Sure enough, she winced and moved the fruit in her mouth. She spat the pit onto the dirt.

“How do you feel?” Crowley asked.

“Much the same.”

“You’ll be surprised what choices will do to you. Sometimes it’s a delayed reaction.”

“What did your choices bring you?”

“Damnation.”

“I feel I am destined for the same.” The woman looked down at the fruit in her hand.

“I will be here, if it’s any consolation.” Crowley jumped down from the branch and landed at her heel. He curled around the fruit pit. “Don’t step on it.”

The woman laughed, still sounding like wind.

“You have surely aided in my fall but seek to protect my heel? Your priorities are misaligned my friend.” She replied, not unfriendly.

Crowley ignored her and took the pit into his jaws and cracked it. The inside was arsenic and a spicy treat.

“So what has changed?” Crowley asked.

“Me.” The woman resolved and took another bite. “And my name is too little for what I am.”

“Really? I think Eve is nice. You’re on the cusp of things, a bringer of things.”

“No, I am a bearer of things.” The woman looked back down at the fruit. “I bear the fruit. To my husband and of my husband. The fruit is damned but I bear it.” She sounded bitter now and Crowley started to feel guilty.

“What will you be called then?”

“Lillith.” The woman said.

When Crowley watched her walk away, he felt that familiar sadness. In the morning, God would know. In the morning, the humans would fall.

He climbed back up the tree to look at the stars.

The Alleluia came softly. It was the way they warmed up. Crowley sang it to himself before the math started in his head.

The Divine numbers that set the scales and time. It fed him notes and he sang, louder as his essence ached.

The rejoice turned into apology and then sorrow. He had been abandoned and he was lonely. The Angelic language burned in his throat but Crowley sang. It was mournful and full of regret.

Just not regret for his actions. He did not mourn his place in heaven.

“Who’s there?” A nervous voice now. Crowley hid and looked down. In the dark, the Angel was illuminated by his flaming sword. He was of the Cherubim, in the same Sphere Crowley had as a Seraph.

“Zophiel? It’s not funny.” The Angel said still looking around. After finding no one, the Angel pouted.

By the eternal fire, an Angel that pouted!

“That’s my song.” The Angel muttered.

Crowley almost fell out of the tree.

“The singing Angel is gone.” Crowley stated as he climbed down. The Angel jumped but waited as he made his way earthward.

“And what are you doing here?” The Angel asked. He sounded authoritative but underneath was a thread of anxiety. This Angel wasn’t supposed to have let Lillith through, let alone this creature.

Someone might get in trouble.

Crowley grinned as best he could with the scales.

“My job. Someone has to.” Crowley added and the Angel blustered.

This one wasn’t like the others, Crowley decided. He might actually be worth conversing with.

Save for one.

An Angel prays through song. But weeping and screaming during a Fall don’t really help the throat.

Crowley, out in the Garden, looked up at the sky. He had prayed after the Fall. He didn’t want to go back, as he had never been happy up there, but he didn’t see why it had to be an All or Nothing kind of deal. Maybe he could stay here, in the Garden. He knew the humans were to be tested, and no snotty Angel was going to want to test them.

“OoOoH what if we are punished for their failure?”

Crowley hissed in displeasure. They covered up their cowardice with privilege. It wasn’t as if the Divine God themself would allow for the exquisite Metatron to debase himself as some sort of trickster for the humans. Let the stupid putti do that.

“God, you saved me from the fools before, save me once again.” Crowley muttered as he clambered through the dense foliage.

He could do it. He would do it if they would let him stay. It was nice here. Not great, but nice. There was no conflict to change things but at least there were creatures to annoy and different things to eat. (The roses gave him a twisting gut though.)

“Let me stay.” Crowley whispered. “Let me have the peace you promised us all up there. I never got the chance.”

He was glum. Not quite self-pitying like the other demons, just put out. He wondered why he had been made at all if he was just going to come out wrong.

“You’re never wrong.” Crowley said as he tried to barter. “And my Divine Purpose couldn’t’ve been to end up damned. That’s not fair.”

There was a clearing and a light ahead. There was no need for a light in the Garden and the nights were filled with the ethereal twinkling of the stars anyway.

“An Angel.” Crowley determined in a mocking tone. He slithered away till he found a private place. There was no one here he really wanted to talk to, not really. Maybe one, if she was as interesting as he hoped.

More than the Garden, Crowley really did like the Woman. She was shaped by the Creator but made, literally, of Man. She was the first earth made thing and that pleased Crowley for some reason. Created, but with the imperfect dust in her very blood.

It made her special. Unlike anything else in the whole Garden.

Adam named her, of course, which irked Crowley. She should have her own name, and her own place in all this mess.

When she ultimately found him, on that night, Crowley was surprised.

“And what are you called?” Her voice, like wind, made him jump in the branches.

“Ah, well, ehm.” Crowley cleared his throat and hid behind some leaves. “I’m Crowley. Now. Wasn’t before. Didn’t much like that name though. Too many syllables.”

Crowley babbled as he darted over branches, trying to escape her curious eyes.

“You can change your name?” She asked. Questions, only questions so far. Adam made statements and this one questioned. That wouldn’t do her any good, Crowley knew that from experience.

“Sure. Hey, should you be here?” Crowley asked. He was sure there had been that same Angel guarding this tree. The Angel that kept getting distracted to go look at something.

“Should you? Did Aziraphale let you in here too?” The woman asked. Crowley stopped on a branch, making a face as he tilted his head back and forth.

“Not quite.” Crowley admitted.

The woman’s face suddenly appeared as she moved some of the leaves. She looked surprised, but not disgusted.

“Why do you look like that?” She asked.

“A little bit of everything isn’t it? I like it. I used to look like the Angel.” Crowley remarked.

“Your eyes.” She said and Crowley turned his head. “They look like his sword.”

He puffed up a bit at that.

“How can I change?” She asked suddenly and Crowley deflated.

“Nothing changes here. You’d need conflict for that.”

“How do I find conflict?”

“By making a choice. Usually one that contradicts what someone else has said.”

“What is a choice?”

Crowley sighed and ambled over the branch. He bumped into a jeweled fruit and quite suddenly had an idea.

“God told you not to eat of this tree.” Crowley said. He didn’t know what was so special about this tree, it seemed much like the others. The fruit didn’t even taste that great and it had a sizeable pit.

“You just have to ask yourself, do you want to try it?” Crowley asked.

The woman looked at the tree, at the fruit that Crowley had begun to coil around.

She nodded.

“I do.”

A simple vow, a simple choice. Crowley moved away from the fruit and the Woman grabbed it.

“Mind the stone. It would hurt you given half a chance.” Crowley advised as she bit into it. Sure enough, she winced and moved the fruit in her mouth. She spat the pit onto the dirt.

“How do you feel?” Crowley asked.

“Much the same.”

“You’ll be surprised what choices will do to you. Sometimes it’s a delayed reaction.”

“What did your choices bring you?”

“Damnation.”

“I feel I am destined for the same.” The woman looked down at the fruit in her hand.

“I will be here, if it’s any consolation.” Crowley jumped down from the branch and landed at her heel. He curled around the fruit pit. “Don’t step on it.”

The woman laughed, still sounding like wind.

“You have surely aided in my fall but seek to protect my heel? Your priorities are misaligned my friend.” She replied, not unfriendly.

Crowley ignored her and took the pit into his jaws and cracked it. The inside was arsenic and a spicy treat.

“So what has changed?” Crowley asked.

“Me.” The woman resolved and took another bite. “And my name is too little for what I am.”

“Really? I think Eve is nice. You’re on the cusp of things, a bringer of things.”

“No, I am a bearer of things.” The woman looked back down at the fruit. “I bear the fruit. To my husband and of my husband. The fruit is damned but I bear it.” She sounded bitter now and Crowley started to feel guilty.

“What will you be called then?”

“Lillith.” The woman said.

When Crowley watched her walk away, he felt that familiar sadness. In the morning, God would know. In the morning, the humans would fall.

He climbed back up the tree to look at the stars.

The Alleluia came softly. It was the way they warmed up. Crowley sang it to himself before the math started in his head.

The Divine numbers that set the scales and time. It fed him notes and he sang, louder as his essence ached.

The rejoice turned into apology and then sorrow. He had been abandoned and he was lonely. The Angelic language burned in his throat but Crowley sang. It was mournful and full of regret.

Just not regret for his actions. He did not mourn his place in heaven.

“Who’s there?” A nervous voice now. Crowley hid and looked down. In the dark, the Angel was illuminated by his flaming sword. He was of the Cherubim, in the same Sphere Crowley had as a Seraph.

“Zophiel? It’s not funny.” The Angel said still looking around. After finding no one, the Angel pouted.

By the eternal fire, an Angel that pouted!

“That’s my song.” The Angel muttered.

Crowley almost fell out of the tree.

“The singing Angel is gone.” Crowley stated as he climbed down. The Angel jumped but waited as he made his way earthward.

“And what are you doing here?” The Angel asked. He sounded authoritative but underneath was a thread of anxiety. This Angel wasn’t supposed to have let Lillith through, let alone this creature.

Someone might get in trouble.

Crowley grinned as best he could with the scales.

“My job. Someone has to.” Crowley added and the Angel blustered.

This one wasn’t like the others, Crowley decided. He might actually be worth conversing with.
trail.content_abstract:
They all used to pray. Even the Big Guy. It was outlawed to speak the Creator’s name, but they were demons.

Many of the smaller ones, the ones from the lower tiers, wept as they did so. Before the halls of Hell even had one soul, it was full of weeping.

It was rumored those smaller ones disappeared to be shades.

Over the years, the prayers stopped and their angelic threads finally, completely, turned to bitter rot.

Save for one.

An Angel prays through song. But weeping and screaming during a Fall don’t really help the throat.

summary: Aziraphale gazed at the slate colored ceiling of the last place he imagined he'd find himself on the evening of the apocalypse....
body:
Aziraphale gazed at the slate colored ceiling of the last place he imagined he’d find himself on the evening of the apocalypse. “Crowley?”

The demon in question, currently wrapped in his arms, stirred sleepily. “Hm?”

“I’m sorry,” he said, smoothing the wrinkles of the Egyptian cotton sheets. “When you asked me —Alpha Centuari — I, well, I wanted to go…”

Crowley shifted his head against the angel’s chest. “Turned out alright though, didn’t it?”

“Well, yes,” the Aziraphale replied. “But I still feel simply awful. And I’m sorry.”

“S'alright,” he assured before cheekily adding, barely above a whisper, “I forgive you.”

And with that, a little bit more of hell and heaven burned away.

trail.content:
Aziraphale gazed at the slate colored ceiling of the last place he imagined he’d find himself on the evening of the apocalypse. “Crowley?”

The demon in question, currently wrapped in his arms, stirred sleepily. “Hm?”

“I’m sorry,” he said, smoothing the wrinkles of the Egyptian cotton sheets. “When you asked me —Alpha Centuari — I, well, I wanted to go…”

Crowley shifted his head against the angel’s chest. “Turned out alright though, didn’t it?”

“Well, yes,” the Aziraphale replied. “But I still feel simply awful. And I’m sorry.”

“S'alright,” he assured before cheekily adding, barely above a whisper, “I forgive you.”

And with that, a little bit more of hell and heaven burned away.
